name: Turkestan Gecko
description: It has an inconspicuous coloration typical of desert lizards—yellowish-gray dorsally and white ventrally.
spread_note: Central Asia – southeastern Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan, Kyrgyzstan, northeastern Iran, northern Afghanistan
food_note: Insects (beetles and others), spiders, and other invertebrates
image_alt: Turkestan gecko, photo: Prague Zoo archive
proportions: Length up to 17 cm, including tail 8–10 cm; weight up to 3.5 g
reproduction: Females lay 1–2 eggs; hatchlings emerge after 49–62 days.
attractions: Unlike other geckos, it lacks adhesive pads on its toes but uses long toes with thin, sharp claws to cling to vertical surfaces easily. Except in spring, it is active only at dusk.
breeding: Prague Zoo has kept this species since 2012 and successfully breeds it.
